title: Park Kwang-on
text:
Park Kwang-on (<a href="Korean%20language">Korean</a>: 박광온, born 26 March 1957) is a South Korean broadcaster and politician. He is the incumbent <a href="National%20Assembly%20%28South%20Korea%29">Member of the National Assembly</a> for <a href="Suwon">Suwon</a> 4th constituency since 2014, as well as the former Secretary-General of the ruling <a href="liberalism">liberal</a> <a href="Democratic%20Party%20of%20Korea">Democratic Party</a> from 2020 to 2021. He was one of the Vice Presidents of the party from 2018 to 2020. Before entering to politics, he worked at <a href="Munhwa%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation</a> (MBC) from 1984 to 2011.
Born in <a href="Haenam%20County">Haenam</a>, Park holds a bachelor's degree in sociology from <a href="Korea%20University">Korea University</a> and a master degree in communication sciences from <a href="Dongguk%20University">Dongguk University</a>. He entered to MBC in 1984 and served various positions, including correspondent, reporter, news reader and so on. He served as a correspondent in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> from 1997 to 2000 and weekend news leader for "<a href="MBC%20Newsdesk">MBC Newsdesk</a>" from 2000 to 2002. He also served as the MC of "<a href="MBC%20100%20Minutes%20Debate">MBC 100 Minutes Debate</a>" from 2010 to 2011.
Park left MBC and entered to politics in 2011. Prior to the <a href="2012%20South%20Korean%20legislative%20election">2012 election</a>, he contested <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28South%20Korea%2C%202011%29">DUP</a> <a href="preselection">preselection</a> for <a href="Haenam%20County">Haenam</a>-<a href="Wando%20County">Wando</a>-<a href="Jindo%20County">Jindo</a> constituency, but lost to the incumbent <a href="Kim%20Yung-rok">Kim Yung-rok</a>. Instead, he became a spokesperson for <a href="Moon%20Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a>, DUP's presidential candidate <a href="2012%20South%20Korean%20presidential%20election">in 2012</a>. He was selected as the <a href="New%20Politics%20Alliance%20for%20Democracy">NPAD</a> candidate for <a href="Suwon">Suwon</a> 4th constituency at the <a href="2014%20South%20Korean%20by-elections">2014 by-election</a>, after <a href="Kim%20Jin-pyo%20%28politician%29">Kim Jin-pyo</a> resigned in order to run as the Governor of <a href="Gyeonggi%20Province">Gyeonggi</a>. He defeated <a href="Lim%20Tae-hui">Lim Tae-hui</a> of the then ruling <a href="Saenuri%20Party">Saenuri Party</a> and subsequently became the NPAD's sole winner in <a href="Seoul%20Capital%20Area">Seoul Capital Area</a>. He was re-elected <a href="2016%20South%20Korean%20legislative%20election">in 2016</a>. <a href="2018%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Korea%20leadership%20election">In August 2018</a>, he ran as a vice presidential candidate of the Democratic Party and won as 2nd.
On 15 October 2018, Park and his Anti-Fake News Committee requested <a href="Google">Google</a> Korea to remove <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a> contents that include fake news related to <a href="Gwangju%20Uprising">Gwangju Uprising</a>, President <a href="Moon%20Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> and so on. However, Google rejected their request, and added that "it's not easy to catch out which one is real and fake". The opposition <a href="Liberty%20Korea%20Party">Liberty Korea Party</a> criticised their request as "media control".
On 31 August 2020, Park was appointed the new Secretary-General of the Democratic Party, under the new President <a href="Lee%20Nak-yon">Lee Nak-yon</a>.
